item.title: Assessments
item.description:
Assessments will include Individual and Team Preparations, Quizzes, Homework, and Exams. As part of these assessments, you will be asked to upload documents to Blackboard, take tests via Blackboard, create videos and upload these into Blackboard, and upload documents to a Google Drive folder.

Course Membership

Components in this category can take many forms including an introductory video you create/submit, weekly check-ins, active participation in the class, and reflections on your learning. In no way, however, will this component be a direct reflection of class attendance. One planned component is explained below.

Check-in: We are each being impacted by and dealing with the current Covid-19 crisis in different ways. Nearly every week I will ask you to submit a short response to a prompt on what you are doing to cope during these times. Each week will be slightly different with respect to what you are submitting, but you will typically provide some form of media (a single word, emoji, animated GIF, meme, image of a piece of art, song, etc.) and write a brief explanation for your selection.

In addition to doing weekly check-ins in this course, I have partnered with six other faculty from across campus to do similar check-ins within their courses. Responses from these courses will be combined and summarized. We will spend portions of class time discussing these responses from students around GVSU. To facilitate this, you will submit your responses in a Google Form (shared with you on Blackboard) that requires you to login with your GVSU network account. None of your personally identifiable information (e.g., name) will be shared with other students; however, your responses to these prompts will be viewable by other students. Additionally, students in some of these courses will use the combined, de-identified data for class projects.

Each Check-in will be worth 1 point and your submission will be graded on whether your response is thoughtful, well-written, and shows engagement with the prompt. Notice that this is essentially a completion-based system. I am not grading your writing ability and I am not counting the exact number of words you are writing. I am looking for thoughtful engagement, that is all. Do good work and you will earn the point. If you prefer to not have your responses available to students outside of the class, contact your professor for an alternative assignment.

Individual Preparation Quizzes

Each Learning Module will begin with completion of an Individual Preparation quiz. An Individual Preparation quiz will be administered via Blackboard and typically composed of approximately twelve questions (multiple-choice, short answer, etc.) based on the assigned Learning Module readings. An Individual Preparation score will be based on the number of correct answers. You will have up to three attempts for each Individual Preparation; the score from the last attempt completed prior to the submission deadline will be recorded as you grade. Each Individual Preparation will consist of randomly-generated items so one attempt will likely differ from the next.

Team Preparation Discussions

Team Preparation discussions will be completed using the Discussion Board feature within the group space in Blackboard. Grading will be primarily based on timeliness of a response and whether the content of the response is substantive. For each Learning Module, you are required to start a discussion (by a specified deadline) and to add to at least one discussion (by another specified deadline) which were started by other team members. Each Team Preparation is worth up to four points (up to two points related to the starting of a discussion and up to two points related to the adding to a discussion started by a fellow team members).
Team Preparation contributions must be “substantive postings” (of both quality and reasonable length). For instance, when you add to a discussion topic, statements of simple agreement in response to a topic (i.e., “I agree” or “Good answer”) lack substantive content; your added comment should further the discussion of the prompt topic in a substantial way.

Application Quizzes

During the semester, there will be (at least) 20 Application Quizzes. Typically, an Application Quiz is attached to an activity and will be administered as a test via Blackboard. Whereas Individual and Team Preparations can thought of as a Learning Module pre-test, an Application Quiz can be viewed as a post-test for an activity. An Application Quiz is designed as a way to assess your understanding of the ontent in an activity prior to attempting Homework. An Application Quiz will typically be assigned at the end of a class session and due 2 hours before the next class session.

Despite their collective importance, the completion of an Application Quiz is optional. Application Quizzes are not part of the regular course points used to determine the base letter grade. However, the completion or non-completion of the Application Quiz can impact the final semester grade that is reported (see Grade Determination).

Homework

Ten homework assignments are planned. SAS-program-based homework will be uploaded into a shared Google folder. Homework involving interpretations and explanation will be completed as a “test” via Blackboard. Homework will be graded; however, not all assigned questions, in part or partial, may factor into the homework grade. Only the top eight homework scores will be used in determining course grades. The exact dates of a homework will be announced at least one week in advance.

Exams

There will be five examinations – one corresponding to each Learning Module. The due date/time for the semester examinations will be announced at least a week in advance. An exam may include a portion completed via a Blackboard Test (multiple-choice, short answer, etc.) and a portion that involves submission of a video recording of yourself (both visual and auditory) explaining answers to provided prompts based on a scenario. You will have a window of time (typically at least 48 hours) in which complete and submit an examination. The portion of an exam completed as a Blackboard Test will be time limited. There will also be a maximum time limit imposed on any video portion of an exam. More details about the specifics of an exam, including when it is due, will be provided prior to each examination. You will upload any document used in guiding your completion of the video portion of an examination in Blackboard.

item.title: Technology
item.description:
To use the course tools, you will need to have access to:

  • A laptop or tablet device.
  • A modern web browser. Google Chrome or Microsoft Edge are preferred, though Mozilla Firefox should also work.
  • Reliable access to high-speed internet.
  • Use a webcam during Blackboard class sessions. In order to increase active participation and engagement in this class, students are expected to turn on their webcam during Blackboard meetings. Students that do not wish to be on camera or are unable to use a camera (e.g., due to technical difficulty or lack of access to a device with a camera) should communicate with their instructor.

If you have any issue with accessing the above for whatever reason, let me know as soon as possible. I may know of resources that can help you for your particular case.

Additionally, we will use SAS via SAS OnDemand for Academics, Blackboard, Panopto, and the Google Suite apps (e.g., Google Docs and Google Drive).

SAS

We will access SAS through SAS OnDemand for Academics. Directions for how to create an account and login will be provided in Blackboard.

Blackboard

All assignments, documents, and grades will be posted on the Blackboard course site. You will also use this for submitting most of your assignments.

Panopto

Panopto is a tool that we will use to submit the video portion of your exams and is free for you to use with your GVSU login. An early task will have you practice the process of creating and uploading a video file to Blackboard using Panopto.

Google Suite

Activities will be provided to as links on Blackboard which will take you to a Google Doc. Team Google Drive folders will be created for you to assist in collaborating on these activities. Directions for how to do this will be provided in early activities.

In addition to activities, we will use Google Drive to submit the SAS portion of Homework assignments. We will discuss how to submit these files in a class session closer to the first Homework due date.

item.title: Getting Help
item.description:
You can ask questions about anything at any time without judgment.

Community Discussion

All asynchronous course discussions will occur in the Community discussion forum on Blackboard. This is a private discussion forum and only students in our class can participate in it. However, this forum is not a place to discuss personal information such as grades or private concerns - that would be best to email me about. I will be available to assist you, but your peers will also be a great resource. I encourage you to seek help in ways that are visible to others so that all can benefit.

One of our first tasks will be to create a post to help you become comfortable with this process.

Class Sessions

You may prefer to get your questions answered live. Each section of STA 216 will meet synchronously in live sessions through Blackboard Collaborate this semester. These sessions will be recorded and available to all students in that section afterwards. Leading up to these sessions, I will solicit additional items beyond what I have planned to cover through the Community discussion forum on Blackboard. If you post items to this forum at least two hours prior to the session, I will do my best to plan a brief demonstration, lesson, etc. covering them. Live sessions are an excellent opportunity to ask questions about course material, assignments, or other course details.

Attendance

Again, each class session will be live-streamed so that you can participate remotely. It is critical that you actually attend these sessions. Note that GVSU has strengthened its attendance policy for Winter 2021 that states that you are expected to be in attendance at synchronous online meetings.

Individual Sessions

You are also welcome to meet with me individually (or bring along your team members). Individual sessions are an excellent opportunity for you to ask questions about graduate schools, research opportunities, or careers in statistics or data science. Additionally, during individual sessions you can ask me about your grades or other personal items.

Due to public health concerns, all student meetings this semester will be conducted remotely unless you have a specific need that requires a physical meeting outside of class. Email me to let me know that you would like to meet in-person and we will arrange a socially distanced-meeting.

I typically check email between 7 am and 5 pm on weekdays and occasionally during the weekend. I do my best to respond promptly to any email, but please do not expect an immediate response. I may need up to 6 hours to respond depending on my schedule and the length of my response.

Student Drop-In Hours

Monday, Tuesday, and Thursday from 1:00 – 2:00 pm I will be available online for drop-in visitors. A Google Meet video conference link has been shared with you on Blackboard where you can access these sessions. You do not need an appointment to attend. If you cannot attend these Student Drop-In Hours, you can contact me by email or by scheduling an appointment in the Google Calendar that is shared with you on Blackboard.

item.title: Grade Determination
item.description:
We use a weighted grading system in this course. Although individual grade components will have points attached, the weight will be used to determine course grades. Grades will be maintained in Blackboard so you can determine your current grade at any time.

Source Weighted Percent
Class Membership 2%
Individual Preparation (top 4) 12%
Team Preparation (top 4) 6%
Homework (top 8) 20%
Exams (5 total) 60%

Final Grade

Your course grade is determined using two steps. First, your base grade (The letter A, B, C, D, or F without plus or minus) is determined using the table provided below.

Criteria Base Grade
≥ 90.0% A
≥ 80.0% B
≥ 70.0% C
≥ 60.0% D
< 60.0% F

Second, once your base grade has been determined, a plus/minus distinction may be added to your base grade. Note that I cannot award an “A+” or a “D-” since these grades do not exist at GVSU.
plus (+) A “plus” may be added to your base grade if you have earned at least 80% of the Application Quiz points and earned at least an 80% on Exam 5.
minus (-) A “minus” may be added to your base grade if you have earned less than 60% of the Application Quiz points or earned less than 60% on Exam 5.

Errors in Grading: While I strive for grading accuracy, mistakes in grading may still occur. If you feel a mistake in grading has occurred (i.e. grade entry error, calculation error), alert me within one week from when the grade in question was entered into Blackboard. After a week has passed following entry of a grade, I will assume that any entered grade is correct unless you communicate to me otherwise. As such, it is important that you take ownership of your grade throughout the semester!

item.title: Learning Modules
item.description:
All materials for these modules will be shared through the Blackboard course site.

  • Module 1: Introduction to Statistical Modeling and SAS
    • Activity 1.1: Introduction to Statistical Modeling and Terminology
    • Activity 1.2: Introduction to SAS Output
    • Activity 1.3: Introduction to SAS Programming
    • Activity 1.4: Introduction to the Four-Step Modeling Approach with SAS
  • Module 2: One-Way Analysis of Variance
    • Activity 2.1: Choose
    • Activity 2.2: Fit and Assess
    • Activity 2.3: Use
  • Module 3: Two-Way Analysis of Variance
    • Activity 3.1: Additive Models
    • Activity 3.2: Introduction to Interaction
    • Activity 3.3: Interaction Models
  • Module 4: Simple Linear Regression
    • Activity 4.1: Choose
    • Activity 4.2: Fit
    • Activity 4.3: Assess
    • Activity 4.4: Use
  • Module 5: Multiple Linear Regression
    • Activity 5.1: Choose
    • Activity 5.2: Fit
    • Activity 5.3: Assess
    • Activity 5.4: Assess with Transformations
    • Activity 5.5: Use

item.title: Policies
item.description:
Academic Integrity

The university’s academic integrity policy is described in the GVSU Student Code, Section 4. Every student has the responsibility of reading and understanding these policies, especially the consequences for engaging in academically dishonest behaviors.

There are many times where you can collaborate on tasks throughout this course; however, at times collaboration may not be allowed. Collaboration guidelines for each kind of activity you complete in this course follow.

  • Individual Preparation Quizzes: You may not interact with another person.
  • Team Preparation Discussions: You may not interact with another person on developing your initial response, but are expected to participate in the ongoing discussion.
  • Application Quizzes: You may collaborate with others, but your submission must be your own.
  • Homework: You may collaborate with others, but your write-up must be in your own words. You may not copy someone’s work or copy the ideas from someone and simply change the wording to submit it as your own.
  • Blackboard Exams: You may not interact with another person. Any evidence of using information from another person or source will be investigated as academic dishonesty.
  • Video Exams: You may discuss ideas about what points need to be included with a prompt, but your submission must be you talking to me using your own thoughts and words. Excessive similarities in submitted work will be investigated as academic dishonesty.

All suspected instances of academic dishonesty will be thoroughly investigated, and whether a student has committed academic dishonesty is my determination to make based on the evidence. If I determine academic dishonesty has been committed, I will file a report with the Dean of Students, and the minimum penalty will be a zero on that assignment. Note that this is a minimum penalties. Additional penalties may be given from the university including reduction of course grades and potential suspension.

A friendly reminder. There is no need to commit academic dishonesty as I am available to help. If you come to believe that cheating or plagiarism is necessary given your situation, do not do it! Get some help instead and remember that you can submit your best effort, get feedback, and be more prepared for later assignments.

Late Work

Deadlines for course work will be clearly indicated in the Blackboard Calendar. If there are apparent conflicts between dates, let me know so I can correct the issue.

  • Individual Preparation Quizzes, Team Preparation Discussions, and Application Quizzes: No extensions or deadlines are available. You may submit an Individual Preparation past the due date, feedback will be provided, but no score will be recorded.
  • Homework: You have up to two 12-hour extensions that can be used on any homework (even the same homework) if I am contacted in advance.
  • Exams: No extensions or deadlines are available.

Technology

Your instructor is not able to provide support for any technological issues. If you encounter issues with technology, use one of the following resources:

  • For help with Blackboard: Email the GVSU Blackboard Help Desk (bbadmin@gvsu.edu) or call (616) 331-8526. For hours and more information see https://www.gvsu.edu/elearn/help.
  • For help with the GVSU network, email, or printing: Email the GVSU IT Help Desk at helpdesk@gvsu.edu or call (616) 331-2101 or toll-free (855) 435-7466. For hours and more information see https://www.gvsu.edu/it.
  • For help with SAS: Contact SAS Support.
  • For specific help with your computer or device: Contact the GVSU IT Help Desk (see previous bullet) or contact your equipment manufacturer of computer store.
  • For help with course tools or applications: Ask a question on the Community discussion board, seek out the help documentation in the tool or application, or do a targeted Google search.

Recordings of Blackboard Meetings

Blackboard meetings will be recorded and will be available to students enrolled in this course as a study aid. Recordings will be available for viewing during the Remote Instruction Period subject to the following:

  • Only students enrolled in the [subject class/section] may view the recording.
  • Students may not post or use the recordings in any other setting (e.g., social media) for any purpose. Students who violate this will be subject to student discipline, up to and including expulsion.
  • If faculty have any plan to use the recording for a different class in the future, the faculty member will need written FERPA consent from those students in the current class who are identifiable in any of the recordings. A FERPA consent form signed by all students in the course will also be needed if the recordings are made available to others beyond the classroom on a non-secure digital platform.

Equitable and Inclusive Learning Environment

I strive to create an equitable and inclusive learning environment in our class. It is my goal that you feel able to share information about your experiences as a student. I will keep information that you share with me private to the best of my ability; however, there is some information that may need to be shared with the university, especially regarding sexual misconduct or information about a crime that may have occurred on GVSU’s campus. Below are additional resources available for support.

Title IX, Sexual Misconduct Policy, and Gender- and Sexual-Based Harassment Policy: Title IX makes it clear that violence and harassment based on sex and gender are Civil Rights offenses subject to the same kinds of accountability and the same kinds of support applied to offenses against other protected categories such as race, national origin, etc. Title IX’s sex discrimination prohibition also protects students from discrimination based on gender identity or failure to conform to stereotypical notions of masculinity or femininity. If you or someone you know has been harassed, assaulted, or denied services on the basis of sex or gender, you can find the appropriate resources at https://www.gvsu.edu/titleix or contact the University’s Title IX Coordinator, Theresa Rowland at (616) 331-9530 or rowlanth@gvsu.edu.

Special learning needs: If you have special needs because of learning, physical, or other disabilities, it is your responsibility to contact Disability Support Resources (DSR) at (616) 331-2490 or https://www.gvsu.edu/dsr. DSR will help you arrange accommodations. Then, set up an appointment with me about how I can help in making those accommodations and ensure that they are consistent with your arrangements with DSR.

Student Well-Being: As a student, you may experience a range of issues that can negatively impact your learning, such as anxiety, depression, interpersonal or sexual violence, difficulty eating or sleeping, loss/grief, and/or alcohol/drug problems. These mental health concerns or stressful events may lead to diminished academic performance and affect your ability to participate in day-to-day activities. In order to support you during such challenging times, GVSU provides a number of confidential resources to all enrolled students, including the University Counseling Center https://www.gvsu.edu/counsel or (616) 331-3266 and the Student Ombuds, Takeelia Garrett garrettt@gvsu.edu.

If you have difficulty affording groceries or accessing sufficient food to eat every day, or if you lack a safe and stable place to live, I encourage you to visit Replenish, a food resource for GVSU students. GVSU also provides Special Circumstances and Financial Hardship grants that can be used to assist in paying for many expenses. Contact the Office of Financial Aid & Scholarships at (616) 331-3234 or visit Special Circumstance & Financial Hardship Requests.

If you are comfortable doing so, please speak with me about your circumstances so that I can advocate for you and connect you with other campus resources.

Gender expression and identity: If your state issued identification does not match your preferred name, your name can be updated in some areas (such as Blackboard, mailroom, and your GVSU ID). At GVSU, this is called “myName” and you can request a myName by following these steps:

  1. Login to myBanner, select the Personal Information tab, then select My Profile.
  2. You will be directed to another authentication page where you will be prompted to enter your network credentials.
  3. On the Personal Details section, select Edit on the and enter your myName.

When your myName has been received and reviewed, you will receive an email letting you know either that it has been approved or requesting further information. Once approved, allow up to two days for the myName to be updated across the campus system. More information about myName can be found on the Milton E. Ford LGBT Resource Center’s page.

COVID-19

As you are well aware, we will be having class this semester while trying to navigate a global pandemic that seems to change every day. Although these plans can be scary and demoralizing, I want you to know that GVSU is doing everything in its power to keep people safe from Covid-19. I believe that if we observe reasonable precautions like the ones described here, then while the risk of Covid-19 is still present, there is no reason to be afraid. We will still learn and grow intellectually just as in “typical” times if we stay focused and work together.

What follow are general guidelines for how we can work productively together during STA 216.

Taking care of yourself

Of the utmost importance is taking care of your own physical and mental health during these difficult times. Make sure you are getting sufficient rest, staying connected to friends and family, and giving yourself time and space to do things you enjoy outside of college. The Mayo Clinic provides several tips for maintaining good self-care in our situation.

While we will not be coming to campus for STA 216, you are still implored to perform a self-evaluation each day and if you feel even the slightest bit of sickness or Covid-19 symptoms, stay home. If you have a class that meets on campus, you should be on campus only if you feel completely healthy.

Contingency plans for the semester

We will be “synchronously online” for the semester, but several things could happen that might alter this setup. Here are the initial plans for the most likely of those things.

If the professor is in self-quarantine, but not because of illness:

For example, if my partner becomes sick or if my daily self-assessment directs me to stay at home. In this case, we will continue synchronous online meetings and an asynchronous option might be introduced.

If the professor has a Covid-19 infection:

The entire course will be moved to an asynchronous online format until I am well enough to resume my responsibilities. A substitute instructor may be appointed to grade and give feedback on Preparation and Follow-up tasks and all other graded work will be suspended until I am well enough to grade.

In either of these two cases, you can expect a slowdown in the grading process and substantial changes to the course calendar or syllabus. Please monitor your course announcements daily to ensure you have correct information. Note that these plans may be changed or overridden by university-wide directives as the semester unfolds. Again, the course announcements will be where I post any information.

GVSU Policies

This course is subject to GVSU’s Course Policies.

Changes to this Syllabus

Changes to this syllabus may occur during the semester. These changes will be announced in class and online, and if appropriate, students will be given an opportunity to voice on how the changes will be implemented.

Key Semester Dates

Important dates to keep in mind for this semester are available at the Registrar’s Academic Calendar. I highlight a few here.

  • Classes Begin: Tuesday, January 19
    • Martin Luther King, Jr. Holiday observed Monday, January 18
  • Winter Break: Wednesday, March 10
  • Winter Break: Thursday, April 1
  • Drop Deadline (Grade of “W”): Friday, April 9, 5 p.m.
  • Classes End: Saturday, April 24
  • Final Examination Week: Monday, April 26 – Saturday, May 1

item.title: Team-Based Learning
item.description:
This course will be taught using a Team-Based Learning approach which encourages collaboration and active learning for both individuals and teams. Most in-class time will be spent working on activities that allow you to directly apply key course concepts within the classroom. These activities will be shared with you on Blackboard as Google Docs.

The course is divided into five Learning Modules. Each Learning Module has three components: Preparation, Application, and Assessment.

Preparation

How we prepare for our class sessions is essential for Team-Based Learning. Each Preparation provides an opportunity to demonstrate your comprehension of the reading and course concepts. Each Preparation follows the sequential pattern:

  • Readings: At the start of each Learning Module, you will complete assigned readings outside of class (which may also include watching videos). These readings contain the core concepts and ideas needed to be successful in the Application phase. There will be additional readings as you and your team members progress through the activities within a Learning Module.
  • Individual Preparation Quiz: Each Individual Preparation quiz is a short (12-ish) set of questions composed of multiple-choice and short answer items. These questions will focus on the core concepts and ideas from the readings. The Individual Preparation will be administered via Blackboard as Tests and will be scored on the number of correct answers. You are allowed up to three attempts for each Individual Preparation; the score from your last attempt prior to the submission deadline will be recorded as your Individual Preparation grade. Each Individual Preparation will consist of randomly-generated items so one attempt will likely differ from the next.
  • Team Preparation Discussion: After the deadline for completing an Individual Preparation has passed, you and your team members will complete a Team Preparation discussion for each Learning Module. Team Preparations will be administered via Blackboard using the Discussion Board feature within the Team group space. A Team Preparation for a Learning Module will consist of at least five open-ended questions. Each team member will select one question and provide an initial response, by the specified deadline, to lead-off the discussion thread. Then, each team member must add to at least one existing thread by a specified deadline. A Team Preparation score will be based on two components: the thread started and the combination of threads added to. Each component will be assessed on a completion-based system and and on-task substance (and less so on the “correctness” of a response).
  • Clarifying Discussion: On occasion, a short lecture may be provided to clarify points of confusion which surface from an Individual Preparation quiz or Team Preparation discussion or to “set the stage” for an upcoming activity. I addition to these occurring at the discretion of the professor, there will be a Community discussion board on Blackboard where students can post items they wish further clarification on. Post on this Community discussion will be viewable by all students and questions emailed to the professor may be instructed to instead be posted here so that the response is available to all students. Other students are strongly encouraged to participate in posts made in the Community discussion area.

Both Individual and Team Preparation tasks are designed for you demonstrate baseline knowledge of a Learning Module prior to starting the activities. My intent is to always start a new Learning Module on the first day of class within a week (i.e. either a Monday or a Tuesday, depending on the section). Doing so should provide you with ample time from the last prior class in which to complete both the Individual and Team Preparation tasks prior to starting activities.

By at least the end of the last class session in the week prior to the start of a new Learning Module:

  • Readings for new Individual Preparation announced
  • Individual Preparation available in Blackboard
  • Team Preparation questions made available (team members should negotiate who will post starting response to which Team Preparation question)
  • First activity for new Learning Module is made available (along with solutions)

By 48 hours prior to the next class session:

  • Deadline for completing Individual Preparation
  • Deadline for posting start of discussion thread for a Team Preparation question

By start of the next class session:

  • Deadline for adding to at least one discussion thread started by another team member

During the next class session:

  • In-class discussion related to first activity for new Learning Module

We will spend a time during the first class session discussing these details specific to your section. At any point during the semester where you are confused about this process, please ask.

Application

The Preparation portion of a Learning Module is to assure individual accountability to the team. After the Preparation portion is completed, we move into the Application portion. Much of the learning in a Team-Based Learning course occurs through working on a series of activities. The activities require you and your team members to apply concepts from the course readings to a series of scenario-based questions which allow you to demonstrate knowledge of one or more of the course goals.

The number of activities within a Learning Module will vary between three and five. Each activity is composed of a series of questions (multiple-choice, calculation-based , short-answer, explanation, etc.) about a course component (i.e., statistical technique). The Applications for a Learning Module will follow this order:

  • The first activity will be made available via Blackboard as a Google Doc the class session following the due date of the Individual Preparation quiz.
  • During this first class session, you and your team members will work together answering the activity questions. There are planned check points throughout these activities at which point you will contact your professor to have them check your answers and provide clarifying discussion on items you got wrong (or you are not sure why you got an item right!). Your professor will also be cycling through team breakout rooms to be available for intermediate clarification.
  • Usually after this class session, the full activity solutions will be made available. If your team does not complete an activity in class, you will need to do so prior to the next class session. If you get an item wrong:
    • Recheck the readings to see why the indicated answer is correct,
    • Discuss any items of interest among your team members,
    • Make note of any items you would like to bring up for discussion during the next class session by adding it to the Class Agenda forum (in the Community discussion area).
  • There will be a short (3-6 questions) Application quiz after each activity for you to check your current understanding.
  • The next class session will begin discussing any items of interest raised by students (which may involve a full-class discussion).
  • The next activity and corresponding readings will become available prior to the the next class session and the process is repeated until all activities associated with a Learning Module have been completed.

The more advance time you spend preparing for a Learning Module (i.e., doing the readings), the more prepared you should be to complete the activities.

Note that activities are not collected and not graded. The activities are designed for you to check your understanding of the statistical content within STA 216.

Assessment

Each Learning Module includes 1) a graded homework assignment that may include producing and interpreting SAS output, doing hand calculations, and providing interpretations; and 2) an exam. Additional information is provided at Course Grading.

item.title: How To Be Successful
item.description:
The following recommendations are taken from end-of-course evaluations, where students were asked to reflect on the Team-Based Learning experience.

To succeed in the Team-Based Learning classroom consider doing all or most of the following:

  • Keep up with readings both for the Preparation process and the Application process so that you are fully prepared to contribute
  • Attend class every day and be engaged
  • Foster good team engagement by staying on task, asking questions of your teammates about course material, and explaining concepts that you understand to teammates who ask questions
  • Take advantage of your resources including your teammates, your professor, and the Statistics (Tutoring) Center located in A-2-601 MAK and available virtually

To succeed in the Preparation process consider doing all or most of the following:

  • Take notes on the Preparation readings
  • Focus on understanding terms by being able to apply them in the examples in the text
  • Raise questions with your team members to clarify understanding of the content before completing the Individual Preparation quiz

To succeed in the Application process consider doing all or most of the following:

  • Take notes on the post-Preparation readings
  • Keep organized notes on activity questions that need clarified and any supplemental lectures by the professor
  • Complete Learning Module homework problems after each activity rather than waiting until all activities are done
  • Assess your post-activity understanding by re-reading text sections

item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Wowchemy’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further event details, including page elements such as image galleries, can be added to the body of this page.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.

item.title: Writing technical content in Academic
item.description:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.

Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.

On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.

Examples

Code

Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

```python
import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()
```

renders as

import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()

Charts

Academic supports the popular Plotly chart format.

Save your Plotly JSON in your page folder, for example chart.json, and then add the {{< chart data="chart" >}} shortcode where you would like the chart to appear.

Demo:

You might also find the Plotly JSON Editor useful.

Math

Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.

Example math block:

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ 
\left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T 
\left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}
{\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$

renders as

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right |^2}$$

Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.

Example multi-line math using the \\\\ math linebreak:

$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\\\
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$

renders as

$$f(k;p_0^) = \begin{cases} p_0^ & \text{if }k=1, \\
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$

Diagrams

Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.

An example flowchart:

```mermaid
graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]
```

renders as

graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]

An example sequence diagram:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!
```

renders as

sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!

An example Gantt diagram:

```mermaid
gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d
```

renders as

gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d

An example class diagram:

```mermaid
classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
<<interface>> Class01
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
class Class10 {
  <<service>>
  int id
  size()
}
```

renders as

classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
<<interface>> Class01
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
class Class10 {
  <<service>>
  int id
  size()
}

An example state diagram:

```mermaid
stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]
```

renders as

stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]

Todo lists

You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:

- [x] Write math example
- [x] Write diagram example
- [ ] Do something else

renders as

  • Write math example
  • Write diagram example
  • Do something else

Tables

Represent your data in tables:

| First Header  | Second Header |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |

renders as

First Header Second Header
Content Cell Content Cell
Content Cell Content Cell

Callouts

Academic supports a shortcode for callouts, also referred to as asides, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% alert note %}} ... {{% /alert %}}, it will render as an aside.

{{% alert note %}}
A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.
{{% /alert %}}

renders as

A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.

Spoilers

Add a spoiler to a page to reveal text, such as an answer to a question, after a button is clicked.

{{< spoiler text="Click to view the spoiler" >}}
You found me!
{{< /spoiler >}}

renders as

Click to view the spoiler

You found me!

Icons

Academic enables you to use a wide range of icons from Font Awesome and Academicons in addition to emojis.

Here are some examples using the icon shortcode to render icons:

{{< icon name="terminal" pack="fas" >}} Terminal  
{{< icon name="python" pack="fab" >}} Python  
{{< icon name="r-project" pack="fab" >}} R

renders as

Terminal
Python
R

Did you find this page helpful? Consider sharing it 🙌

item.title: An example preprint / working paper
item.description:
Create your slides in Markdown - click the Slides button to check out the example.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code, math, and images.

item.title: Display Jupyter Notebooks with Academic
item.description:
from IPython.core.display import Image
Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png')


print("Welcome to Academic!")

Welcome to Academic!

Install Python and JupyterLab

Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.

Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.

Create or upload a Jupyter notebook

Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:

mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
jupyter lab index.ipynb

The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.

Edit your post metadata

The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata (front matter).

In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:

---
title: My post's title
date: 2019-09-01

# Put any other Academic metadata here...
---

Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.

To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post’s folder.

For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.

Convert notebook to Markdown

jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=.

Example

This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Wowchemy

Wowchemy | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

item.title: Welcome to Wowchemy, the website builder for Hugo
item.description:
Overview

  1. The Wowchemy website builder for Hugo, along with its starter templates, is designed for professional creators, educators, and teams/organizations - although it can be used to create any kind of site
  2. The template can be modified and customised to suit your needs. It’s a good platform for anyone looking to take control of their data and online identity whilst having the convenience to start off with a no-code solution (write in Markdown and customize with YAML parameters) and having flexibility to later add even deeper personalization with HTML and CSS
  3. You can work with all your favourite tools and apps with hundreds of plugins and integrations to speed up your workflows, interact with your readers, and much more

Get Started

  • 👉 Create a new site
  • 📚 Personalize your site
  • 💬 Chat with the Wowchemy community or Hugo community
  • 🐦 Twitter: @wowchemy @GeorgeCushen #MadeWithWowchemy
  • 💡 Request a feature or report a bug for Wowchemy
  • ⬆️ Updating Wowchemy? View the Update Guide and Release Notes

Crowd-funded open-source software

To help us develop this template and software sustainably under the MIT license, we ask all individuals and businesses that use it to help support its ongoing maintenance and development via sponsorship.

❤️ Click here to become a sponsor and help support Wowchemy’s future ❤️

As a token of appreciation for sponsoring, you can unlock these awesome rewards and extra features 🦄✨

Ecosystem

  • Wowchemy Admin: An admin tool to automatically import publications from BibTeX

Inspiration

Check out the latest demo of what you’ll get in less than 10 minutes, or view the showcase of personal, project, and business sites.

Features

  • Page builder - Create anything with widgets and elements
  • Edit any type of content - Blog posts, publications, talks, slides, projects, and more!
  • Create content in Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio
  • Plugin System - Fully customizable color and font themes
  • Display Code and Math - Code highlighting and LaTeX math supported
  • Integrations - Google Analytics, Disqus commenting, Maps, Contact Forms, and more!
  • Beautiful Site - Simple and refreshing one page design
  • Industry-Leading SEO - Help get your website found on search engines and social media
  • Media Galleries - Display your images and videos with captions in a customizable gallery
  • Mobile Friendly - Look amazing on every screen with a mobile friendly version of your site
  • Multi-language - 34+ language packs including English, 中文, and Português
  • Multi-user - Each author gets their own profile page
  • Privacy Pack - Assists with GDPR
  • Stand Out - Bring your site to life with animation, parallax backgrounds, and scroll effects
  • One-Click Deployment - No servers. No databases. Only files.

Themes

Wowchemy and its templates come with automatic day (light) and night (dark) mode built-in. Alternatively, visitors can choose their preferred mode - click the moon icon in the top right of the Demo to see it in action! Day/night mode can also be disabled by the site admin in params.toml.

Choose a stunning theme and font for your site. Themes are fully customizable.

License

Copyright 2016-present George Cushen.

Released under the MIT license.
